text: So I ran the derivative and convertible sales and strategy effort. I was part of this leadership team that reported to the head of global market sales. And so once a week we would all get into a conference room. It would be myself, the head of mortgage sales, the head of credit derivative sales, and their trading counterparts as well. And I used to hear a lot about the Magnetar trade. And essentially this was some trade, very controversial in some people's eyes, but effectively it was a transaction involving the tranches in CDOs that in some ways allowed the kind of daisy chain of risk-taking in the mortgage arena to continue. It was a brilliant, brilliant transaction. But I kept hearing about it and I started to try to learn more about what was going on in credit derivative sales. As I got to know these guys better, they were starting to say, you know, things are really feeling like if one thing goes wrong, the sizes are so gigantic that this whole system could crack. And that could be in corporate CDS. It could be in this giant system of mortgages and the trades and the credit expansion that had come about through the housing bubble. I started working on their behalf. They were looking to try to hedge credit risk, looking for some alternatives. And yeah, I was working with our head of structuring on the equity derivative side. We came up with this idea of buying an option on a variant swap. So a variant swap, synthetic instrument, allows you to get long or short realized volatility. Very, very big product, especially in the pre-GFC period. Well, these guys weren't in a position to just do the swap. They needed to know exactly. How much they could lose. Look, what's interesting about equity vol or about risk premium in general is that when something gets really low, it looks mouthwateringly cheap. But you just got to respect the fact that it got that low. It was brought to that level by a certain set of conditions that made the previous trade so unprofitable, so loss making that you just have to think it could get worse still. Sometimes these things feed on themselves in the other direction. So they needed a trade that allowed them to pay out a certain amount of premium. And if their long volatility bet designed to hedge credit risk went horribly wrong, they'd lose a specific fixed amount. And so we were left effectively to price not just the variance swap. That was actually easy. But the option on the variance, which was effectively some version of vol of vol, it was a precursor to options on the VIX. This was. 2005. And again, it helped me see that things in the credit markets were moving at a speed that the equity vol market was behind. Things definitely started to get funky the summer of 07. But even after Bear Stearns, asset management in June 07, the quant quake in August 07, by October 07, the equity market was at an all time high. Now, it wasn't a below 10 VIX. So vol had gone higher. There was some repricing, but credit was way ahead. Way ahead. And if you really talk to enough people about the set of things that was in motion from a systemic risk standpoint, and I'm certainly not claiming I got it all right by any stretch. But to me, it's humbling, you know, sometimes on a backward looking basis to see some of what was available that you could have learned if you truly does not. So again, enough. One of my favorite things, just really quickly, I think I might have mentioned this to you. There's I've read my fair share of books on the financial crisis. There's one I think is very under followed under read. It's called Fatal Risk. It's on AIG specifically. And AIG was really the last provider of subprime CDS. They insured the entire street. There's this very controversial decision made by the Treasury Secretary Geithner to make the counterpart. Parties to AIG FP whole. They made Sock Gen whole. They made Goldman whole. And there's testimony where he's, I think, on the Hill with Warren, Senator Warren, grilling him over why is Goldman Sachs made whole? Listen, I'm not here to argue that. It's just that AIG had such a giant book on this stuff. And as you read through this book, Fatal Risk, you realize that one of the things that really set in motion the financial crisis. Was them losing their AAA status. AAA counterparties don't post any collateral ever. No mark to market collateral, no upfront collateral. It's a poison chalice. It's something that will allow your book to get so much bigger than it otherwise would be. And so once they lost the AAA, they started to have to post. And those postings just got more and more sizable. There's a lot of discussion in Michael Lewis's book, The Big Short, about the back and forth with. Deutsche Bank and Goldman and AIG. So you just look back on these things. And to me, it's just humbling because sometimes it's there if you can really put the pieces of the puzzle together. But it can be very tough to do.
